body.para: is a game engine for running Ultima 8 on modern operating systems. Since a modified version of the Ultima 8 engine also powered the two Crusader games (Crusader: No Remorse and Crusader: No Regret) our ultimate goal is to be able to run those two as well. Right now we don't support them but you will be the first to know when we do.

sub.name: name_origin
sub.header: Why is it called - are you satanists or something?

body.para: If you ever played Ultima 8 or bought the first release of the game, then you will have noticed the big pentagram on the game box and the intro. That is the sole reason for this name.

No, the team will not accept donations. For us there are greater legal matters involved, which none of us particularly want to explore. We do not want to risk the wrath of EA for directly profiting from . If you want to donate to anyone, donate to Sourceforge. We wouldn't be here if it weren't for them.

Furthermore since we have never managed to make contact with EA or Origin while working on Exult we didn't even try to contact them this time. So, no, Origin and EA do not support and will most likely just ignore questions about us.

sub.name: snapshot
sub.header: Binary, snapshot, source tree - what are you talking about?

body.para: First of all, if you are running Windows and you just want to run/play , download the SVN Snapshot binary called Windows Binary.

Source is the code of Pentagram and is only useful for programmers that want to look at it, compile it or, hopefully, want to contribute to the project. Once you compile the code you get a binary or in other words the actual program.
SVN snapshots are the newest source code. Whenever we change some code, Travis and Dominus make a new snapshot the next day. As we currently have no releases, snapshots are the only way for you to run .

sub.name: old_snapshot
sub.header: And what is that old snapshot supposed to be?

body.para:
For that you'll have to take a look at 's history.
The project started out as a pet project by some of the Exult programmers. We tried to figure out the various file formats and used a sub tree of the Exult source code space. For example we developed a map viewer, a shapes viewer (shapes are the graphic files of Ultima 8) and many other tools.
Only when the code of became more mature we decided to make it a separate project. The code developed so far was taken over to the new project space as the "old" module but we still worked on it.
Since the code that was written was meant for small viewer programs and not for a full game engine, we decided to start from scratch on itself.
Some of the tools in the old snapshot are not yet ported over to the actual Pentagram code and therefore users and programmers might find it still useful. A listing of the tools follows.

ul.li:
unpackshp
The most useful tool now. If you don't have u8shapes.flx in the static subdirectory, you have to use this tool on u8shapes.cmp to have it decompressed.

dcmpsound
Sound and Voice effects in Ultima 8 were compressed with Sonarc. Dcmpsound uses u8.exe of the original game to decompress the sfx into something we can use. For dcmpsound to find u8.exe and the sfx flex files you have to edit pentagram.cfg.

dcmpsound2
Same purpose as dcmpsound, only it doesn't use u8.exe to decompress the sfx.

u8extract
Extracts the archives Ultima 8 used to store its files. Their file ending is .flx and they are called flex files.

u8savextract
Used to extract savegames. The initial game is also a savegame and to actually start the game we needed to figure the savegame format out. And no, apart from the initial savegame, you can't run other savegames from the original.

dequote
Shows you the content of the quotes files (quotes.dat and ecredit.dat).

shpdisp
Lets you browse through the graphics of the game. See the readme that comes with it for more details.

animdisp
Lets you browse through the animations of the game. See the readme that comes with it for more details.

globdisp
Lets you browse through the globs of the game. See the readme that comes with it for more details.

mapdisp
Lets you browse through the maps of the game. See the readme that comes with it for more details.

sub.name: u8_versions
sub.header: Does work with all versions of Ultima 8?

body.para: Ultima 8 was released in English, French, German, Spanish and Japanese. All five should run in , but the non-English versions, especially the Japanese version, need much more testing.

On a side note, we heard that the Spanish version might not have been actually finishable. At some point in the game you are supposed to get the Tear of Seas from Devon but the conversation option might not be there.

sub.name: lost_vale2
sub.header: Will the Lost Vale run on ?

body.para: Unfortunately the add-on for Ultima 8, called the Lost Vale was never released. Rumor has it that it was actually finished but Origin/EA decided there was no market for it and lost it.

sub.name: old_saves
sub.header: Do save games from the original work in ?

body.para: No. Although we did figure out the savegame format and are able to run the initial one, we can't load other savegames from the original. The way the original saved processes prevents us from loading them, only the initial savegame has no processes running.

sub.name: save_compat
sub.header: Do savegames work on all operating systems?

body.para: Yes. savegames are compatible between all supported operating systems. For example a game saved on Mac OS X works on Windows XP as well.

sub.name: obtain_u8
sub.header: Where can I obtain a copy of Ultima 8?

body.para: If you do not already own a legal copy of Ultima 8, the team highly suggests you buy a copy. We suggest searching for Ultima 8 on sites such as Ebay or used software sites. Stores which sell used games are often good places to try as well.

You also might want to look for the Ultima Collection, which contains all the previous Ultima games as well. It is also typically easier to find than Ultima 8 because it was released much more recently.

sub.name: filthy_pirate
sub.header: Can you give me a copy or tell me where to download Ultima 8?

body.para: No! The team does not and never will support piracy.
Members of the team will likely ignore, flame, or even banish you to another world where no one has ever heard of the Avatar if you ask them for a pirated copy of any Ultima.

No, if an entity still exists to claim the rights over a piece of software (EA in the case of Ultima 8), and the company has not openly given away those rights to make the software free, then the software does not fall under the term abandonware or freeware.
Any copies of Ultima 8 you find on the Internet that claim to be abandoned or free are neither, and downloading them will be considered piracy.

sub.name: against_piracy
sub.header: Why does the team feel so strongly on the issue of piracy?

body.para: First, we understand the amount of work that goes into making a game like Ultima 8. If we put ourselves into the same position as the original programmers and artists, we would be against the piracy of our work and feel that something has been stolen from us directly when piracy occurs.

Second, the team does not want to alienate any former or current members of Origin or EA. Some have been helpful in the past in informing us, and we have a great deal of respect for them. We also wish to avoid any possible legal issues which could threaten to end the project.
